column4: Is there a page that tells you what EXACTLY to do when you are trying to install Ubuntu on a laptop and properly partion that hard drive?
Anyone?
What about the defaul layout is not acceptable?
I can't blow away the XP partition
So don't?
I need a walkthru for someone who
Have you actually tried running the installer?
I need a walkthru for someone who's never done this before
Yes, I have. I've been running Ubuntu since Warty

If there is free space on the disk, there is nothing else you need to do.  The installer will give the option to "Leave existing partitions in place and use available space for installation".  If you're looking to resize your XP because you have no free space, then yes, you'll want to use gparted.
The installaer in Dapper is a lot different than previous releases.
In so much as it's pointy clicky and runs as an application under the live desktop.  The partitioner is a bit easier to use as well.
So gparted runs under the live desktop?
I can't say if the live CD comes with a repartitioning program, but you can certainly install one once running the live desktop in order to manipulate your disks.
Ah, OK.
It's nice using the live CD for this because you get a "full install of Ubuntu" that doesn't keep your hard disks in use, and thus in a state where they can't be modified by partitioning software.
As for actually using gparted, I've not done so for.... almost 10 years. ;-)  So I can't really offer much advice beyond "boot the live CD, install the partition editing software, and go from there."
You should be able, however, to get back on IRC from the booted live CD.
Ah, that's the other thing. The Live CD doesn't detect the wireless card :/

doh!  The easiest work around, if it's possible for you, would be to plug in an Ethernet cable.  As for getting wireless running on Linux, that's not something I've tackled so I can't advise you further on it.
(I'm sure there are others in here who can, though). ;-)
